newsitem.title: JAPAN: Dlr to test 127 yen in Asia if no surprises at G7.
newsitem.headline: Dlr to test 127 yen in Asia if no surprises at G7.

text.p: The dollar is likely to edge higher against the yen and may test 127 yen in Asia on Monday if a statement by the Group of Seven (G7) nations fails to yield anything new, dealers said.
"Chances the G7 statement is unlikely to yield anything new may lift the dollar to 127 yen, but then caution over intervention would likely grow," said a Japanese bank dealer.
A senior Japanese official said in Washington on Sunday that Japan and the United Stated had agreed not to specifically say what they meant by "concern about recent developments of the yen".
The G7 meeting ended a short while ago in Washington and traders are keenly awaiting the release of the statement.
After a weekend meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, U.S. President Bill Clinton told reporters: "(It) is not our economic policy to go out and seek a weak dollar."

"Given this comment (from the U.S. side), chances are high that nothing new will come out of the G7 meeting," said the bank dealer. He said the market has been short on the dollar, with stop-loss buying expected to take place on rises.

"But the dollar's movements above 127 yen would become nervous because of possible dollar-selling intervention," said the Japanese bank dealer. "If there is no sign of intervention, the dollar is likely to rise further to 128 yen," he added.
The dollar rose as high as 127.16 yen earlier this month.
Even if intervention takes place and the dollar falls, bids by investors are expected to emerge at 124.50 yen, he added.

Another Japanese bank dealer said Japanese exporters are expected to sell dollars above 127 yen, which could slow the dollar's rise. Dealers said the dollar/mark is likely to move in tandem with the dollar/yen.
